body_html:
Hi @marshalhayes

Thanks . - you are correct. Apparently Mac high sierra comes with Python installed but not pip ( presumably you installed it on an older version?) .
I installed the latest python binary - and then I ran.
sudo -H python -m ensurepip which seems to have got it working.

I am onto the next step - but it doesn't seem very clear. Ideally in getting started tutorials the docs should walk users through the basics ideally using copy/ paste commands and ideally it would be cool to have a seperate tab for specific implementation like Google do for swift/ Objective C

( I have updated the documentation below to try help others. )


 $ virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow, # for Python 2.7

Activate the Virtualenv environment by issuing one of the following commands:

$ cd targetDirectory
$ source ./bin/activate      # If using bash, sh, ksh, or zsh
$ source ./bin/activate.csh  # If using csh or tcsh 
The preceding source command should change your prompt to the following:

 (tensorflow)$ ```

Ideally the documentation should add the lines: 

1. Check what version of python you are running by typing `python` into the terminal
2. If you are running version 2.7 then you can install tensorflow using this command `virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow`
3. cd `~/tensorflow`
4. Activate your Tensorflow Virtual Environment by typing `source ./bin/activate ` ( you do this each time you want to use Tensorflow ( its not clear how I tell if I am using bash, sh, ksh, or zsh / csh as there are no links to help me decide.)
5. You will then see the prompt for command has changed to: `(tensorflow)YOURACCOUNT:tensorflow YOURACCOUNT$ `

6.  etc..```

After that I managed to get it working..( so far!)

( I have updated the documentation below to try help others. )

 $ virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow, # for Python 2.7

Activate the Virtualenv environment by issuing one of the following commands:

$ cd targetDirectory

1. Check what version of python you are running by typing `python` into the terminal
2. If you are running version 2.7 then you can install tensorflow using this command `virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow`
3. cd `~/tensorflow`
4. Activate your Tensorflow Virtual Environment by typing `source ./bin/activate ` ( you do this each time you want to use Tensorflow ( its not clear how I tell if I am using bash, sh, ksh, or zsh / csh as there are no links to help me decide.)

body:
Hi @marshalhayes 

Thanks . - you are correct.  Apparently Mac high sierra comes with Python installed but not pip ( presumably you installed it on an older version?) . 
I installed the latest python binary - and then I ran. 
`sudo -H python -m ensurepip` which seems to have got it working. 

I am onto the next step - but it doesn't seem very clear. Ideally in getting started tutorials the docs should walk users through the basics ideally using copy/ paste commands and ideally it would be cool to have a seperate tab for specific implementation like Google do for swift/ Objective C 

 ( I have updated the documentation below to try help others. )
```Create a Virtualenv environment by issuing a command of one of the following formats:

 $ virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow, # for Python 2.7

Activate the Virtualenv environment by issuing one of the following commands:

$ cd targetDirectory
$ source ./bin/activate      # If using bash, sh, ksh, or zsh
$ source ./bin/activate.csh  # If using csh or tcsh 
The preceding source command should change your prompt to the following:

 (tensorflow)$ ```

Ideally the documentation should add the lines: 

1. Check what version of python you are running by typing `python` into the terminal
2. If you are running version 2.7 then you can install tensorflow using this command `virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow`
3. cd `~/tensorflow`
4. Activate your Tensorflow Virtual Environment by typing `source ./bin/activate ` ( you do this each time you want to use Tensorflow ( its not clear how I tell if I am using bash, sh, ksh, or zsh / csh as there are no links to help me decide.)
5. You will then see the prompt for command has changed to: `(tensorflow)YOURACCOUNT:tensorflow YOURACCOUNT$ `

6.  etc..```

After that I managed to get it working..( so far!)
